p: Regarding diterpenes, more than one million tons a year [ 147] of residue is produced after steam distillation of pine resin to recover the volatile fraction called turpentine. The consequent by-product is the gum rosin, which is a mixture of resin acids (90â€“95%) and other neutral compounds. The resin acids, most of which are isomers of each other, can be classified into two main categories: abietic-type (including abietic, neoabietic, palustric, and levopimaric), and pimaric-type (including pimaric, isopimaric, and sandaracopimaric) [ 148]. Gum rosin is a high-value-added residue, in fact, it is a natural alternative to fossil-based polymers obtained from the heating and evaporation of pine resin [ 149], as well as a producer of organocatalysts to promote complicated asymmetric industrial synthesis [ 150].
